title: Polish factory worker loses job at UK manufacturer 'due to bosses' Brexit fears'
text:

A factory worker from Poland claims his contract with a UK manufacturer was terminated because of bosses' Brexit fears.

Sebastian Gajda said he was shocked and angry after being told he was losing his job at Bartoline Limited, which makes decorating products, in Beverley, East Yorks.

Mr Gajda, 25, was hired on a temporary contract last December and was then given a rolling contract, hoping he would one day become a permanent employee.

But he told HullLive he received a letter "out of the blue" telling him his contract was being terminated, leaving him scrambling to find a new job as he aims to remain in Britain.

(Image: Jerome Ellerby)

Mr Gajda, who moved to the UK from Poland in 2017, said: “I joined Bartoline in December last year and my contract ended in July. But I was kept on and I was hoping for a permanent contract.

“But I received a letter this week telling me my contract had been terminated due to issues around Brexit. It was a huge shock to me. I had been in almost every day so I assumed there was plenty of work.”

In the letter, Bartoline fillers and adhesives production manager Charles Weston writes: “The business is about to enter a potential turbulent time with the exit from the EU.

“While we do not expect any long term issues, we may experience a dip in orders as we enter the changeover period.

(Image: Jerome Ellerby)

“To ensure that we are in the best position to deal with any change, it is with regret that I will need to terminate your contract.

“I would like to thank you for your hard efforts in the past and wish you all the best in securing another suitable position.”

Mr Gajda, who lives in Hull, was given an extra week’s notice beyond the statutory week.

But he said: “I am angry as this came out of the blue. There was no indication my job was under threat.

(Image: Jerome Ellerby)

“Even though I have come from Poland I was not that worried about Brexit so it is a huge shock to find I have been so directly affected. I don’t know of any other workers at the company who have lost their jobs because of this.

“I have no plans to return to Poland and I will just have to try and find a new job. I have just bought new car insurance and I was settling down here.”

Alexandra Jastrzebska, who runs the Polish Bureau in Hull, said: “I have never seen anything like this before and I couldn’t believe Brexit was given as a reason to lose your job. This seems to me to be an awful reason and I worry whether it will happen to anyone else.

“We don’t know if it is Polish or eastern Europeans that are at risk or is it English people too?

“I just hope the Polish community are not being targeted as we pay our taxes and contribute to the community and love being here."

Bartoline has been contacted for comment.

Mr Gajda received the letter as Prime Minister Boris Johnson tried to reach a new Brexit deal with EU leaders.

Mr Johnson appealed to MPs to back his last-minute deal in an extraordinary sitting of Parliament on Saturday as his opponents attempted to derail the legislation.

Parliament was sitting for the first time on a Saturday in 37 years as the October 31 deadline drew closer.

But the Prime Minister faced another hurdle with opposition MPs threatening to vote for an amendment withholding approval until legislation to implement the deal is in place.

Sir Oliver Letwin, the former Cabinet minister who had the Tory whip withdrawn after rebelling over Brexit, said it was an "insurance policy" to prevent Britain "crashing out" without a deal on October 31.
description: Sebastian Gajda was shocked and angry after being told he was losing his job at Bartoline in Beverley, East Yorks, because Britain is entering a "potential turbulent time" with Brexit
